Chapter 1

Example 1.3: Classifying categorical observations into two states

We have two firms, a reliable firm AA with P(A)=0.7P(A) = 0.7 and a less reliable firm ACA^C with P(AC)=1−0.7=0.3P(A^C) = 1 - 0.7 = 0.3.

PrA <- 0.7 # Probability of items being produced by the reliable firm
PrAC <- 1 - PrA # Probability of items being produced by the less reliable firm

The failure rate, i.e. the probability of a faulty item, is 0.01 for the reliable firm AA and 0.05 for the less reliable firm ACA^C.

PrFA <- 0.01 # Failure rate of the reliable firm
PrFAC <- 0.05 # Failure rate of the less reliable firm

Assume that we observe any number of failures yy between 0 and 6 (from N=100N = 100 observations total), but we don’t know whether the items are from company AA or ACA^C.

N <- 100
y <- 0:6

We can now compute the probability of dealing with items from company AA by using Bayes’ theorem.

PosteriorTheta1Unormalized <- PrFA ^ y * (1 - PrFA) ^ (N - y) * PrA
PosteriorTheta0Unormalized <- PrFAC ^ y * (1 - PrFAC) ^ (N - y) * PrAC
NormalizingConstant <- PosteriorTheta0Unormalized + PosteriorTheta1Unormalized

round(PosteriorTheta1Unormalized / NormalizingConstant, 3)
#> [1] 0.993 0.965 0.842 0.505 0.164 0.036 0.007

Of course, the probabilities of dealing with items from company ACA^C are complementary.

round(PosteriorTheta0Unormalized / NormalizingConstant, 3)
#> [1] 0.007 0.035 0.158 0.495 0.836 0.964 0.993
